title: Spaghetti Carbonara
description: A classic Roman pasta dish of al dente spaghetti tossed with a silky sauce made from eggs, Pecorino Romano, and rendered guanciale (or pancetta). The result is rich, savory, and comforting with a peppery finish and no cream — quick to prepare for a satisfying weeknight dinner.

ingredients.notes: cut into small cubes or lardons
use whole eggs for authentic texture
extra yolk for silkiness (optional but recommended)
reserve a small amount for finishing

ingredients.display_name: extra-virgin olive oil (only if using very lean pancetta)
ingredients.notes: use sparingly; guanciale usually provides enough fat
starchy water used to adjust sauce consistency

steps.text: Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil, add the salt, then add the spaghetti and cook until very al dente (typically 8–9 minutes depending on brand). Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

While pasta cooks, dice the guanciale (or pancetta) into small cubes. Place in a cold skillet and set over medium heat; render the fat slowly until the pieces are crisp and golden and the fat is released. If the meat is very lean, add a small amount of olive oil to help rendering.

In a mixing bowl, whisk together the whole eggs, extra egg yolk, and about three-quarters of the grated Pecorino Romano until smooth. Add a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper and whisk to combine. This is the sauce base; do not heat it directly.

When spaghetti is nearly done, scoop and reserve at least 150 ml of the starchy cooking water. Immediately transfer the pasta from the pot to the skillet with the rendered guanciale using tongs (do not add more water to the pot). Toss over low heat for 30–60 seconds so the pasta picks up some fat.

Remove the skillet from the heat and quickly pour the egg-and-cheese mixture over the hot pasta, tossing vigorously with tongs or stirring rapidly to create a creamy emulsion. Add reserved pasta water a little at a time as needed to loosen the sauce and achieve a silky coating without scrambling the eggs.
Taste and adjust seasoning with remaining Pecorino and additional black pepper. Serve immediately in warmed bowls, finishing each portion with a sprinkle of cheese and a final crack of black pepper.
